content: FORT PRESQUE ISLE NATIONAL HISTORIC SITE, PENNSYLVANIA. Fort Presque Isle was a frontier outpost in Erie, Pennsylvania, with American installations built in 1795 and 1796. General Anthony Wayne, a Revolutionary War hero, arrived in the area in 1786. He was known as "Mad" for his leadership and bravery, not for being reckless. The original blockhouse of Fort Presque Isle was built in 1795 by 200 Federal troops under Captain John Grubb. General Wayne died at the fort in 1796 and was buried there. The blockhouse burned in 1852, and a new structure was built in 1880 as a memorial. The reconstructed blockhouse at Fort Presque Isle was built in 1880 as a memorial to General Wayne. The Pennsylvania Historical and Museum Commission has recognized it as eligible for the National Register of Historic Places. The purposes of this section include reconstructing the frontier fort for the benefit of the people, preserving General Wayne's grave site, and enhancing understanding of Fort Presque Isle's historical significance. The Fort Presque Isle National Historic Site in Erie, Pennsylvania is established as a unit of the National Park System. It consists of land and improvements comprising the historic location of Fort Presque Isle, including a blockhouse replica. The term "historic site" refers to this establishment, and the term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The Fort Presque Isle National Historic Site in Erie, Pennsylvania covers approximately ________ acres. The map and boundary description are available for public inspection in the office of the Director of the National Park Service. The Secretary will administer the historic site in accordance with relevant laws. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with interested individuals or agencies to further the purposes of the National Park Service Organic Act and the Historic Sites, Buildings, and Antiquities Act. Technical assistance for preservation of historic structures and cultural landscapes can be provided to eligible persons. The Secretary can acquire real property for the historic site through donation, exchange, or purchase. Eligible persons include property owners within the site boundary and those who have agreements with the Secretary. A general management plan must be completed by a specified deadline. The Secretary must prepare a general management plan for the historic site in consultation with relevant officials and submit it to Congress. Authorization of appropriations is provided. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the Secretary to carry out the preparation of a general management plan for the historic site in consultation with relevant officials.
